Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I was sweeping up the last bits of hair when Mrs. Goldstein stormed back into the salon, her voice echoing off the mirrors. “This is not what I asked for!” she shouted, gesturing wildly at her uneven bangs. I glanced at the clock—ten minutes to six. The salon was supposed to close, but more pressing, I was due at the synagogue in fifteen minutes to teach the children their weekly Torah lesson. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Religious school starts soon!” I could already picture the kids waiting, their parents expecting me to guide them, to be patient and wise. But here, in my apron, scissors still in hand, I was expected to be calm, attentive, and fix this woman’s hair, no matter how late it was. My heart pounded as I tried to listen to her complaints, but my mind was already at the synagogue, feeling the weight of both my scissors and my siddur. I stood there, torn, the demands of my two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
